title: Stable homotopy theory
summary: In mathematics, stable homotopy theory is the part of homotopy theory (and thus algebraic topology) concerned with all structure and phenomena that remain after sufficiently many applications of the suspension functor.  A founding result was the Freudenthal suspension theorem, which states that given any pointed space X {\displaystyle X} , the homotopy groups π n + k ( Σ n X ) {\displaystyle \pi _{n+k}(\Sigma ^{n}X)} stabilize for n {\displaystyle n} sufficiently large. In particular, the homotopy groups of spheres π n + k ( S n ) {\displaystyle \pi _{n+k}(S^{n})} stabilize for n ≥ k + 2 {\displaystyle n\geq k+2} . For example,
